div.head: THE EPISTLE TO THE READER.
div.p:
HAving drawn up these my Thoughts into this Form, in order to the satisfying of a Private
Christian, I was moved to let them passe forth into the Publick out of a hope that the publication thereof might be helpful towards the hindring of the further spreading of that Disease, for which I had provided this Remedy. Many I saw were the Means by which men are hindred from the Duty there urged: Some need therefore I judged there was of acquainting
them, both with the Reasons for it, and Motives to it. The judgment of my design I leave to thee, the successe to God. One thing I desire of thee, viz. to conceive that urging it as a General Duty upon all Members of the Church of Christ qualified by Age and understanding for such a Performance, I do include and presuppose the conscientious
performing of all previous duties predisposing and preparing thereunto. And with this grain of Salt, if thou take what is offered thee, it may become both savoury and beneficial to thee. If thou canst not agree with me in all, yet agree with me in what thou canst: and make not that, which was designed to heal, be an occasion of increasing differences. Too
many already are too busie at that work. If my discourse shall at any time presse hard upon thy Opinion, or upon thy practice, consider not so much what thou mayst reply to me, or the world, but what thou oughtest to answer to God, and thine own Conscience about it. And take heed of a wilful shutting thine eyes against an offer'd light. If thou shalt overtake
me in any Fault (from which I do not professe my self free) do not reprove me with Words of bitternesse, but restore me in the Spirit of metknesse, considering thy self, lest thou also be tempted. And beware that the discovery of a supposed errour, harden thee not into a Refusal of a certain truth. Of the Concealment of my Name (lest that offend thee)
take this account. My meaning herein is, that thou shouldest not judge of my Book by my Person, but of my Person (if thou wilt needs be judging) by my Book. 'Tis an ill Course, though the Usual Course, to measure a Doctrine by it's Teacher: the Teacher should be measured by his Doctrine. Then is our affection rightly placed, when we love the
Teacher for the Truths sake, and the Truth it self, not for its Teachers but for its own sake. Consider therefore, not who I am, but what I say: and of what is said, take Thou the Profit, give Me the Pardon, and for the Praise ascribe it wholly unto God; to whose mercy and goodnesse I commend Thee, being desirous to be recommended thereunto
by thee, as being
